item.title: Rain Drops: Condensation and Acceleration
item.description: Problem Solution Problem Problem 49, page 189 in Simmons (2016) Newtonâ€™s second law of motion \[ F = ma = m \frac{dv}{dt} \] can be written in the form \[ \begin{equation} F = \frac{d \left( mv \right)}{dt} \tag{1} \label{momentum-rate} \end{equation} \] in terms of the momentum \(mv\) of a particle of mass \(m\) and velocity \(v\), and remains valid even if \(m\) is not constant. A spherical raindrop falls through air with water vapor, and assume that by condensation the mass of the raindrop increases at a rate proportional to its surface area, with \(c\) the constant of proportionality.
